senses.gloss: The occurrence of events by chance in a happy or beneficial way.
senses.example: A fortunate stroke of serendipity brought the two old friends together.

senses.gloss: Lasting for a very short time; transitory.
senses.example: The ephemeral beauty of cherry blossoms captivates visitors each spring.

senses.gloss: Fluent or persuasive in speaking or writing.
senses.example: She delivered an eloquent speech that moved the entire audience.

senses.gloss: A typical example or pattern of something; a model.
senses.example: The discovery represented a paradigm shift in scientific thinking.

senses.gloss: Present, appearing, or found everywhere.
senses.example: Smartphones have become ubiquitous in modern society.

senses.gloss: Open to more than one interpretation; not having one obvious meaning.
senses.example: The ending of the film was deliberately ambiguous.

senses.gloss: Related to the mental action or process of acquiring knowledge and understanding through thought, experience, and the senses.
senses.example: Reading regularly can improve cognitive function.

senses.gloss: Dealing with things sensibly and realistically in a way that is based on practical rather than theoretical considerations.
senses.example: She took a pragmatic approach to solving the problem.

senses.gloss: Able to withstand or recover quickly from difficult conditions.
senses.example: The community proved resilient in the face of adversity.

senses.gloss: Having or showing the ability to speak fluently and coherently.
senses.example: He was an articulate advocate for social justice.

senses.gloss: To express an idea or feeling fluently and coherently.
senses.example: She articulated her concerns clearly to the committee.

senses.gloss: Certain to happen; unavoidable.
senses.example: Change is inevitable in any growing organization.

senses.gloss: A feeling or state of intense excitement and happiness.
senses.example: The team was in a state of euphoria after winning the championship.

senses.gloss: A sentimental longing or wistful affection for the past.
senses.example: The old photographs filled her with nostalgia.

senses.gloss: Showing great attention to detail; very careful and precise.
senses.example: The scientist kept meticulous records of every experiment.

senses.gloss: The ability to understand and share the feelings of another.
senses.example: Good teachers show empathy towards struggling students.

senses.gloss: The quality of being honest and having strong moral principles.
senses.example: She was known for her integrity and fairness.

senses.gloss: Featuring new methods; advanced and original.
senses.example: The company developed an innovative solution to reduce waste.

senses.gloss: Existing in thought or as an idea but not having a physical or concrete existence.
senses.example: Truth and beauty are abstract concepts.

senses.gloss: To consider something theoretically or separately from something else.
senses.example: We can abstract the key principles from these examples.

senses.gloss: Well meaning and kindly.
senses.example: A benevolent smile spread across her face.

senses.gloss: A person or thing that precipitates an event or change.
senses.example: The invention was a catalyst for industrial revolution.

senses.gloss: Having or showing care and conscientiousness in one's work or duties.
senses.example: She was a diligent student who never missed an assignment.

senses.gloss: Unconventional and slightly strange.
senses.example: His eccentric behavior made him memorable at parties.

senses.gloss: Treating serious issues with deliberately inappropriate humor.
senses.example: His facetious remarks during the meeting were not appreciated.

senses.gloss: Fond of company; sociable.
senses.example: She's a gregarious person who loves meeting new people.

senses.gloss: A supposition or proposed explanation made on the basis of limited evidence as a starting point for further investigation.
senses.example: Scientists test their hypothesis through careful experimentation.

senses.gloss: Belonging naturally; essential.
senses.example: The intrinsic value of education goes beyond career prospects.

senses.gloss: To place or deal with close together for contrasting effect.
senses.example: The exhibit juxtaposes ancient and modern art.

senses.gloss: Relating to or resulting from motion.
senses.example: Kinetic energy increases as an object speeds up.

senses.gloss: Full of or shedding light; bright or shining.
senses.example: The luminous moon illuminated the night sky.

senses.gloss: Generous or forgiving, especially toward a rival or less powerful person.
senses.example: In a magnanimous gesture, she forgave her opponent.

senses.gloss: A subtle difference in or shade of meaning, expression, or sound.
senses.example: The poem is full of nuance and deeper meaning.

senses.gloss: No longer produced or used; out of date.
senses.example: Floppy disks are now obsolete technology.

senses.gloss: Never ending or changing; occurring repeatedly.
senses.example: The machine promised perpetual motion, which physics says is impossible.

senses.gloss: Representing the most perfect or typical example of a quality or class.
senses.example: She is the quintessential professional, always prepared and courteous.

senses.gloss: To respond to a gesture or action by making a corresponding one.
senses.example: She smiled at him, and he reciprocated warmly.

senses.gloss: Of considerable importance, size, or worth.
senses.example: The company made a substantial profit this quarter.

senses.gloss: Perceptible by touch; clear and definite; real.
senses.example: There are tangible benefits to regular exercise.

senses.gloss: The fact of appearing everywhere or of being very common.
senses.example: The ubiquity of social media has changed how we communicate.

senses.gloss: Using or expressed in more words than are needed.
senses.example: His verbose writing style made the report difficult to read.

senses.gloss: Playfully quaint or fanciful, especially in an appealing and amusing way.
senses.example: The artist's whimsical sculptures delighted children and adults alike.

senses.gloss: Dislike of or prejudice against people from other countries.
senses.example: The rise in xenophobia concerned human rights advocates.

senses.gloss: A feeling of intense longing for something.
senses.example: She felt a deep yearning to return to her homeland.

senses.gloss: Having or showing zeal; fervent or enthusiastic.
senses.example: The zealous volunteers worked late into the night.

senses.gloss: Concerned with beauty or the appreciation of beauty.
senses.example: The building has great aesthetic appeal.

senses.gloss: A set of principles underlying the work of a particular artist or artistic movement.
senses.example: The minimalist aesthetic emphasizes simplicity and functionality.

senses.gloss: Concise and exact use of words in writing or speech.
senses.example: The brevity of his speech was appreciated by the tired audience.

senses.gloss: Showing smug or uncritical satisfaction with oneself or one's achievements.
senses.example: We must not become complacent about our early success.

senses.gloss: Humble submission and respect.
senses.example: The young employees showed deference to the company founder.

senses.gloss: A person or thing that is mysterious, puzzling, or difficult to understand.
senses.example: She remained an enigma to her colleagues.

senses.gloss: Not having any serious purpose or value.
senses.example: The court dismissed the frivolous lawsuit.

senses.gloss: The quality of being thankful; readiness to show appreciation.
senses.example: She expressed her gratitude for their support.

senses.gloss: The quality of forming a pleasing and consistent whole.
senses.example: The colors in the painting exist in perfect harmony.

senses.gloss: Extremely distressing or disturbing; acutely painful or traumatic.
senses.example: She gave a harrowing account of her escape from the war zone.

senses.gloss: A system of ideas and ideals, especially one which forms the basis of economic or political theory and policy.
senses.example: The party's ideology attracted younger voters.

senses.gloss: Special words or expressions used by a profession or group that are difficult for others to understand.
senses.example: The medical jargon made the report incomprehensible to laypeople.

senses.gloss: Facts, information, and skills acquired through experience or education.
senses.example: She has extensive knowledge of Renaissance art.

senses.gloss: Something handed down from an ancestor or predecessor.
senses.example: His legacy lives on through his charitable foundation.

senses.gloss: The impetus and driving force gained by the development of a process or course of events.
senses.example: The campaign gained momentum as more people joined.

senses.gloss: A spoken or written account of connected events; a story.
senses.example: The book weaves together multiple narratives.

senses.gloss: Not influenced by personal feelings or opinions in considering and representing facts.
senses.example: Journalists strive to maintain objective reporting.

senses.gloss: A goal or aim.
senses.example: The team's objective is to launch by December.

senses.gloss: A particular attitude toward or way of regarding something; a point of view.
senses.example: Try to see the situation from her perspective.

senses.gloss: The standard of something as measured against other things of a similar kind.
senses.example: We focus on quality rather than quantity.

senses.gloss: Based on or in accordance with reason or logic.
senses.example: She made a rational decision after weighing all options.

senses.gloss: To cause to occur or operate at the same time or rate.
senses.example: The dancers synchronized their movements perfectly.

senses.gloss: Concerned with or involving the theory of a subject rather than its practical application.
senses.example: The course focuses on theoretical physics.

senses.gloss: Relating to or done by all people or things in the world or in a particular group; applicable to all cases.
senses.example: Music is a universal language.

senses.gloss: To check or prove the validity or accuracy of something.
senses.example: The scientist validated the results through repeated experiments.

senses.gloss: The quality of having experience, knowledge, and good judgment.
senses.example: She shared her wisdom with younger colleagues.

senses.gloss: A strong desire to do or achieve something.
senses.example: Her ambition drove her to succeed against all odds.

senses.gloss: Favorable or advantageous; resulting in good.
senses.example: Regular exercise is beneficial for your health.

senses.gloss: To work jointly on an activity or project.
senses.example: The two companies collaborated on developing new technology.

senses.gloss: Showing a great deal of variety; very different.
senses.example: The city has a diverse population from many backgrounds.

senses.gloss: Involving many carefully arranged parts or details; detailed and complicated.
senses.example: The wedding featured elaborate decorations.

senses.gloss: To develop or present a theory, policy, or system in detail.
senses.example: Could you elaborate on your proposal?

senses.gloss: To make an action or process easy or easier.
senses.example: The new software facilitates collaboration across teams.

senses.gloss: Truly what something is said to be; authentic.
senses.example: She showed genuine concern for her students.

senses.gloss: A system in which members of an organization are ranked according to relative status or authority.
senses.example: The company has a flat hierarchy with few management levels.

senses.gloss: To explain or make something clear by using examples, charts, pictures, etc.
senses.example: The diagram illustrates how the system works.

senses.gloss: The action of showing something to be right or reasonable.
senses.example: He struggled to find justification for his decision.

senses.gloss: Conforming to the law or to rules; able to be defended with logic or justification.
senses.example: She raised several legitimate concerns about the plan.

senses.gloss: A system of methods used in a particular area of study or activity.
senses.example: The research methodology was clearly described in the paper.

senses.gloss: Famous or well known, typically for some bad quality or deed.
senses.example: The city is notorious for its traffic congestion.

senses.gloss: Best or most favorable; optimum.
senses.example: We're searching for the optimal solution to the problem.

senses.gloss: Widespread in a particular area at a particular time.
senses.example: Flu is prevalent during winter months.

senses.gloss: Relating to or measured by the quality of something rather than its quantity.
senses.example: The study used qualitative research methods.

senses.gloss: Closely connected or appropriate to what is being done or considered.
senses.example: Please include only relevant information in your report.

senses.gloss: Sufficiently great or important to be worthy of attention; noteworthy.
senses.example: The findings represent a significant breakthrough.

senses.gloss: To make a thorough or dramatic change in the form, appearance, or character of.
senses.example: Technology has transformed how we communicate.

senses.gloss: Being the only one of its kind; unlike anything else.
senses.example: Each person's fingerprints are unique.

senses.gloss: Able to adapt or be adapted to many different functions or activities.
senses.example: She's a versatile actor who can play any role.

senses.gloss: A comparison between two things, typically for the purpose of explanation or clarification.
senses.example: He used an analogy to explain the complex concept.

senses.gloss: Logical and consistent; forming a unified whole.
senses.example: She presented a coherent argument for the proposal.

senses.gloss: Complete; including all or nearly all elements or aspects of something.
senses.example: The report provides a comprehensive analysis of the market.

senses.gloss: Living or occurring at the same time; belonging to or occurring in the present.
senses.example: The museum features contemporary art from around the world.

senses.gloss: A principle or standard by which something may be judged or decided.
senses.example: Academic merit is the main criterion for admission.

senses.gloss: Relating to the structure of populations.
senses.example: The study examined demographic trends in urban areas.

senses.gloss: Based on observation or experience rather than theory or pure logic.
senses.example: The conclusions are supported by empirical evidence.

senses.gloss: An essential supporting structure; a basic structure underlying a system, concept, or text.
senses.example: The law provides a framework for environmental protection.

senses.gloss: Suggested though not directly expressed; implied.
senses.example: There was an implicit understanding between them.

senses.gloss: The basic physical and organizational structures and facilities needed for the operation of a society or enterprise.
senses.example: The city is investing heavily in infrastructure improvements.

senses.gloss: Existing in something as a permanent, essential, or characteristic attribute.
senses.example: There are inherent risks in any investment.

senses.gloss: Coming between two things in time, place, order, character, etc.
senses.example: This course is suitable for intermediate-level students.

senses.gloss: To cite or appeal to someone or something as an authority for an action or in support of an argument.
senses.example: He invoked his constitutional right to remain silent.

senses.gloss: The fact of two things being seen or placed close together with contrasting effect.
senses.example: The juxtaposition of wealth and poverty was striking.

senses.gloss: Relating to or situated at the edge or margin; of secondary importance.
senses.example: The difference in cost is marginal.

senses.gloss: A system of parts working together in a machine; a piece of machinery.
senses.example: The mechanism controlling the door needs repair.

senses.gloss: A fact or situation that is observed to exist or happen, especially one whose cause is in question.
senses.example: The northern lights are a natural phenomenon.

senses.gloss: Denoting an action or event preceding or done in preparation for something fuller or more important.
senses.example: The preliminary results look promising.

senses.gloss: A fundamental truth or proposition that serves as the foundation for a system of belief or behavior.
senses.example: She refused to compromise her principles.

senses.gloss: The official procedure or system of rules governing affairs of state or diplomatic occasions.
senses.example: The data transmission protocol ensures security.

senses.gloss: To bring back to a former condition, place, or position.
senses.example: Workers are restoring the historic building.

senses.gloss: To imitate the appearance or character of; to produce a computer model of.
senses.example: The software can simulate real-world conditions.

senses.gloss: Coming after something in time; following.
senses.example: The initial report and all subsequent updates were reviewed.

senses.gloss: To strengthen or support physically or mentally; to cause to continue.
senses.example: The economy cannot sustain this level of growth.

senses.gloss: Not certain or fixed; provisional.
senses.example: We made tentative plans to meet next week.

senses.gloss: The transmission of customs or beliefs from generation to generation.
senses.example: It's a family tradition to gather for Sunday dinner.

senses.gloss: By that means; as a result of that.
senses.example: Students complete assignments online, thereby saving paper.

senses.gloss: To experience or be subjected to something, typically something unpleasant.
senses.example: The building will undergo extensive renovations.

senses.gloss: Uncomplicated and easy to do or understand.
senses.example: The instructions are straightforward and clear.

senses.gloss: To take in or contain as part of a whole; to include.
senses.example: The new design incorporates feedback from users.

senses.gloss: Based on random choice or personal whim, rather than any reason or system.
senses.example: The decision seemed arbitrary and unfair.

senses.gloss: To gather together or acquire an increasing number or quantity of.
senses.example: Dust had accumulated on the shelves.

senses.gloss: Correct in all details; exact.
senses.example: Please ensure the information is accurate before submitting.

senses.gloss: To buy or obtain an asset or object; to learn or develop a skill.
senses.example: The company acquired a smaller competitor.

senses.gloss: Satisfactory or acceptable in quality or quantity.
senses.example: The training provided was barely adequate.

senses.gloss: Next to or adjoining something else.
senses.example: The two rooms are adjacent to each other.

senses.gloss: To publicly recommend or support.
senses.example: She advocates for environmental protection.

senses.gloss: A person who publicly supports or recommends a particular cause or policy.
senses.example: He's a strong advocate for education reform.

senses.gloss: To distribute resources or duties for a particular purpose.
senses.example: The budget allocates funds for infrastructure projects.

senses.gloss: The quality of being open to more than one interpretation; inexactness.
senses.example: The contract's ambiguity led to disputes.

senses.gloss: Relating to or using analysis or logical reasoning.
senses.example: The report takes an analytic approach to the problem.

senses.gloss: To add something to the end of a written document.
senses.example: Please append your signature to the form.

senses.gloss: To recognize the full worth of; to be grateful for.
senses.example: I really appreciate your help with this project.

senses.gloss: Close to the actual, but not completely accurate or exact.
senses.example: Can you give me an approximate cost?

senses.gloss: To fit together the separate component parts of; to gather together in one place.
senses.example: The team assembled in the conference room.

senses.gloss: To evaluate or estimate the nature, ability, or quality of.
senses.example: Teachers assess student progress throughout the year.

senses.gloss: To allocate a job or duty to someone; to designate or set aside for a purpose.
senses.example: Each team member was assigned specific tasks.

senses.gloss: To help someone, typically by doing a share of the work.
senses.example: Can you assist me with carrying these boxes?

senses.gloss: To suppose to be the case, without proof; to take or begin to have.
senses.example: Don't assume everyone knows what you're talking about.

senses.gloss: To tell someone something positively to dispel any doubts.
senses.example: I assure you that everything will be ready on time.

senses.gloss: To fasten; join; to be connected with.
senses.example: Please attach the document to your email.

senses.gloss: To succeed in achieving something, typically after much effort.
senses.example: She attained the highest score in the class.

senses.gloss: To regard something as being caused by.
senses.example: She attributes her success to hard work.

senses.gloss: A quality or feature regarded as a characteristic or inherent part of someone or something.
senses.example: Patience is an important attribute for teachers.

senses.gloss: A writer of a book, article, or report.
senses.example: The author will be signing books at the store tomorrow.

senses.gloss: The power or right to give orders, make decisions, and enforce obedience.
senses.example: She has the authority to approve the budget.

senses.gloss: Working by itself with little or no direct human control.
senses.example: The doors open automatically when you approach.

senses.gloss: Able to be used or obtained; at someone's disposal.
senses.example: Is the conference room available this afternoon?

senses.gloss: Having knowledge or perception of a situation or fact.
senses.example: We are aware of the challenges ahead.

senses.gloss: In the interests of; as a representative of.
senses.example: She spoke on behalf of the entire team.

senses.gloss: Prejudice in favor of or against one thing, person, or group compared with another.
senses.example: The study was criticized for researcher bias.

senses.gloss: A connection or relationship between people or groups based on shared feelings, interests, or experiences.
senses.example: The two friends formed a strong bond over the years.

senses.gloss: Of short duration; using few words.
senses.example: I'll give you a brief summary of the meeting.

senses.gloss: The mass or magnitude of something large; the majority or greater part.
senses.example: The bulk of the work is already complete.

senses.gloss: Having the ability, fitness, or quality necessary to do or achieve something.
senses.example: She's capable of handling complex projects.

senses.gloss: The maximum amount that something can contain or produce; the ability or power to do something.
senses.example: The stadium has a capacity of 50,000 people.

senses.gloss: A class or division of people or things regarded as having particular shared characteristics.
senses.example: Products are organized by category on the website.

senses.gloss: To come or bring to an end.
senses.example: The company will cease operations next month.

senses.gloss: A call to take part in a contest or competition; a task or situation that tests someone's abilities.
senses.example: The project presents several technical challenges.

senses.gloss: A method or system for communication or distribution.
senses.example: The company uses multiple channels to reach customers.

senses.gloss: A main division of a book; a period of time or an episode in a person's life.
senses.example: This closes a chapter in the company's history.

senses.gloss: A fact or condition connected with or relevant to an event or action.
senses.example: Under the circumstances, we did the best we could.

senses.gloss: Relating to ordinary citizens and their concerns; courteous and polite.
senses.example: Let's keep the discussion civil and respectful.

senses.gloss: To make a statement or situation less confused and more clearly comprehensible.
senses.example: Could you clarify what you mean by that?

senses.gloss: Judged over a period of time to be of the highest quality and outstanding of its kind.
senses.example: The film is considered a classic of cinema.

senses.gloss: A particular and separate article, stipulation, or proviso in a treaty, bill, or contract.
senses.example: The contract includes a cancellation clause.

senses.gloss: A system of words, letters, figures, or symbols used to represent others; program instructions.
senses.example: Developers write code to create software applications.

senses.gloss: To occur at the same time; to be in agreement.
senses.example: Our vacation plans coincide with the school holidays.

senses.gloss: To begin; to start.
senses.example: The ceremony will commence at noon.

senses.gloss: A verbal or written remark expressing an opinion or reaction.
senses.example: The article received hundreds of comments online.

senses.gloss: To carry out or perpetrate; to pledge or bind to a certain course or policy.
senses.example: The company committed to reducing carbon emissions.

senses.gloss: A raw material or primary agricultural product that can be bought and sold.
senses.example: Oil is a valuable commodity in global markets.

senses.gloss: To share or exchange information, news, or ideas.
senses.example: It's important to communicate clearly with your team.

senses.gloss: A group of people living in the same place or having a particular characteristic in common.
senses.example: The local community organized a fundraiser.

senses.gloss: Able to exist or occur together without conflict; able to be used together.
senses.example: Make sure the software is compatible with your operating system.

senses.gloss: To give someone something, typically money, in recognition of loss, suffering, or injury.
senses.example: The company will compensate customers for the inconvenience.

senses.gloss: To produce something by assembling information collected from other sources.
senses.example: Researchers compiled data from thousands of studies.

senses.gloss: A thing that completes or brings to perfection.
senses.example: The wine is a perfect complement to the meal.

senses.gloss: Consisting of many different and connected parts; not easy to analyze or understand.
senses.example: The issue is more complex than it initially appears.

senses.gloss: A part or element of a larger whole.
senses.example: Each component of the system must work together.

senses.gloss: A thing that is composed of two or more separate elements.
senses.example: Water is a compound of hydrogen and oxygen.

senses.gloss: To form or devise a plan or idea in the mind.
senses.example: She conceived a brilliant solution to the problem.

senses.gloss: To focus one's attention or mental effort on a particular object or activity.
senses.example: I need silence to concentrate on my work.

senses.gloss: An abstract idea or general notion.
senses.example: The concept of time is difficult to define precisely.

senses.gloss: To bring something to an end; to arrive at a judgment or opinion by reasoning.
senses.example: The meeting concluded with a vote on the proposal.

senses.gloss: Existing, happening, or done at the same time.
senses.example: She manages multiple concurrent projects.

senses.gloss: To organize and carry out; to lead or guide.
senses.example: The university will conduct a study on student behavior.

senses.gloss: To have discussions; to grant or bestow a title, degree, benefit, or right.
senses.example: The university will confer degrees at graduation.

senses.gloss: To keep or restrict someone or something within certain limits.
senses.example: Please confine your remarks to the topic at hand.

senses.gloss: To establish the truth or correctness of something previously believed or suspected.
senses.example: Tests confirmed the diagnosis.

senses.gloss: A serious disagreement or argument; a prolonged armed struggle.
senses.example: The two departments are in conflict over budget priorities.

senses.gloss: To comply with rules, standards, or laws; to be similar in form or type.
senses.example: All products must conform to safety regulations.

senses.gloss: Permission for something to happen or agreement to do something.
senses.example: Written consent is required before treatment can begin.

senses.gloss: Following as a result or effect.
senses.example: The fire and consequent smoke damage destroyed the building.

senses.gloss: Notably large in size, amount, or extent.
senses.example: The project will require considerable time and resources.

senses.gloss: To be composed or made up of.
senses.example: The committee consists of twelve members.

senses.gloss: Occurring continuously over a period of time; remaining unchanged.
senses.example: The machine requires constant monitoring.

senses.gloss: To be a part of a whole; to be equivalent to.
senses.example: Women constitute 60% of the workforce.

senses.gloss: To severely restrict the scope, extent, or activity of.
senses.example: Budget limitations constrained the project's scope.

senses.gloss: To build or erect something; to form an idea or theory by bringing together various elements.
senses.example: Workers are constructing a new bridge.

senses.gloss: To seek information or advice from someone; to have discussions or confer with someone.
senses.example: You should consult a lawyer before signing the contract.

senses.gloss: To eat, drink, or ingest; to use up a resource.
senses.example: The car consumes a lot of fuel.

senses.gloss: The state of physical touching; communication with someone.
senses.example: I'll be in contact with you next week.
